evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

The airport operator and ATC were notified. Soon after, representatives from the airport operator and the RFFS were on scene. The aircraft sustained substantial damage to the rear of the aircraft, including the APU, which was running at the time.
The TRP on Taxiway Delta is between Stands 61L and 61R. There is a 14.97 m clearance behind a B737-800 and the blast fence when its nosewheel is on the TRP.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew in the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25 is consistently observable and documented in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim scope.

assumptions: The absence of warnings from wingman and headset operator implies communication/coordination breakdown.
Crew roles and training imply expected communication which was not effectively executed.
defeaters: If evidence showed effective communication and timely warnings from wingman or headset operator, or if procedural deviations fully explained the event without communication issues.

quotes.exact_quote: He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.
The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.
The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.
The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H8 directly documents lack of warning signals from wingman and headset operator indicating communication breakdown; H1, H2, H3, and H9 show crew roles and communication context supporting coordination failure rather than procedural deviation.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in distinguishing procedural deviation from communication breakdown without explicit crew communication logs.

node.statement: The communication/coordination breakdown among crew aligns with key features of the incident involving Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25, as captured in the hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim data.

assumptions: Assuming that the described communication methods and crew interactions are representative of the incident's critical coordination aspects.
Assuming no significant environmental or marking deficiencies contributed to the incident beyond what is described.
defeaters: If evidence showed clear, effective communication and coordination among crew or if environmental markings were proven inadequate or misleading, this would challenge the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H1-H4 and H8 directly describe communication and coordination issues among crew during pushback, supporting the claim that communication/coordination breakdown aligns with key incident features. The lack of effective warning signals and failure to stop at the TRP indicate coordination failure rather than environmental marking deficiency.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct contradictory evidence present; uncertainty arises from possible unreported environmental factors or unobserved communication.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution is documented and observable within the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA aircraft during the 12-25 hist_dynamic_und_t2_interim timeframe.

assumptions: The TRP ground markings are assumed to be adequate and visible as per H7.
No mechanical control failure occurred as no evidence indicates such.
defeaters: If evidence showed environmental markings were inadequate or not visible, or if mechanical control failure was documented, this would change the conclusion.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 directly documents the procedural deviation with the aircraft passing the TRP and hitting the blast barrier, and H8 supports that the procedural signals were insufficient and no warnings were given, favoring procedural deviation over environmental causes.
outcome.uncertainty_source: No direct evidence of environmental marking deficiency or mechanical failure; ambiguity remains if other factors contributed.

node.statement: The procedural deviation in pushback execution aligns with key features identified for the Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA during the specified interim period, reflecting relevant operational characteristics.

assumptions: No mechanical faults were detected or reported in the evidence.
The procedural deviation is inferred from the lack of effective stop signals and the trainee's actions.
defeaters: If evidence showed equipment fault traces or bench checks indicating mechanical control failure.
If clear warnings or signals were given but ignored, suggesting communication breakdown.
If environmental factors or marking deficiencies were documented as causes.

quotes.exact_quote: The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

The tug instructor stated that the method for getting a tug driver to stop quickly was to raise a clenched first, indicating the driver should apply the tug’s brakes. However, he suggested such a visual signal was not sufficient given a driver would be concentrating on the pushback, with the headset operator often out of his field of view. He did not receive any warning of the impending collision from the wingman or the headset operator.

Trainee tug driver The trainee driver was qualified as a headset operator and wingman, and was aware of the TRP through the training for these roles. This was her second pushback. The first was completed earlier that day, without event.

outcome.reasoning_summary: Evidence H4 shows the aircraft passed the TRP and hit the blast barrier despite the engine at idle, indicating procedural deviation. H8 explains the signaling method was insufficient and no warnings were given, supporting procedural deviation over mechanical failure. H9 confirms the trainee was trained and aware of the TRP, reinforcing that the deviation was procedural.
outcome.uncertainty_source: ambiguity in signaling effectiveness and lack of direct mechanical fault evidence
